SITypes
  • SIUnit
  • View page source

SIUnit

Declares the SIUnit interface for representing and manipulating physical units.

SIUnit provides an interface for SI and derived units, supporting unit construction, comparison, and conversion. The API is CoreFoundation-style, with explicit memory management and reference counting.

SIUnit objects are immutable by default; use SIMutableUnitRef for mutable variants.

This interface supports querying the symbol, dimensionality, and conversion factors of a unit, as well as unit arithmetic and comparison.

Author

Philip Grandinetti

Copyright

PhySy Ltd.

Typedefs

typedef const struct __SIUnit *SIUnitRef

Type of a reference to immutable SIUnit.

Enums

enum SIPrefix

SIUnit represents the unit of a physical quantity.

An important characteristic of physical quantities is that any given physical quantity can be derived from other physical quantities through physical laws. For example, the physical quantity of speed is calculated as a ratio of distance traveled to time elapsed. The volume of a box is calculated as the product of three quantities of length: i.e., height, width, and depth of the box. Any physical quantity can always be related back through physical laws to a smaller set of reference physical quantities. In fact, as the laws of physics become unified it has been argued that this smaller set can be reduced to simply the Planck length and the speed of light. At the level of theory employed by most scientists and engineers, however, there is a practical agreement that seven physical quantities should serve as fundamental reference quantities from which all other physical quantities can be derived. These reference quantities are:

  • length

  • mass

  • time

  • electric current

  • thermodynamic temperature (the absolute measure of temperature)

  • amount of substance

  • luminous intensity

SI Prefix enumeration.

Values:

SIDimensionalityRef SIUnitGetDimensionality(SIUnitRef theUnit)

Gets unit’s dimensionality.

Parameters:

  • theUnit – The unit.

Returns:

The dimensionality of a unit.

SIPrefix SIUnitGetNumeratorPrefixAtIndex(SIUnitRef theUnit, const uint8_t index)

Gets unit’s numerator root unit prefix for the dimension at index.

Root unit for length, mass, time, current, temperature, amount, and luminous intensity are assigned to index constants kSILengthIndex, kSIMassIndex, kSITimeIndex, kSICurrentIndex, kSITemperatureIndex, kSIAmountIndex, kSILuminousIntensityIndex, respectively.

Parameters:

  • theUnit – The unit.

  • index – The index of the dimension.

Returns:

The integer exponent associated with an SI prefix.

SIPrefix SIUnitGetDenominatorPrefixAtIndex(SIUnitRef theUnit, const uint8_t index)

Gets unit’s denominator root unit prefix for the dimension at index.

Root unit for length, mass, time, current, temperature, amount, and luminous intensity are assigned to index constants kSILengthIndex, kSIMassIndex, kSITimeIndex, kSICurrentIndex, kSITemperatureIndex, kSIAmountIndex, kSILuminousIntensityIndex, respectively.

Parameters:

  • theUnit – The unit.

  • index – The index of the dimension.

Returns:

The integer exponent associated with an SI prefix.

bool SIUnitAreEquivalentUnits(SIUnitRef theUnit1, SIUnitRef theUnit2)

Determines if units are equivalent.

Determines if units are equivalent. If true, these two units can be substituted for each other without modifying the quantity’s numerical value.

Parameters:

  • theUnit1 – The first unit.

  • theUnit2 – The second unit.

Returns:

True or false.

Determines if the two units are equal.

Parameters:

  • theUnit1 – The first unit.

  • theUnit2 – The second unit.

Returns:

True or false.

Calculates the scaling factor needed to transform the numerical value of quantity with this unit into the appropriate numerical value for the coherent si unit of the same dimensionality.

Parameters:

  • theUnit – The unit.

Returns:

SIUnitRef SIUnitFindCoherentSIUnit(SIUnitRef input, double *unit_multiplier)

Returns a coherent SI unit with the dimensionality of input unit.

Parameters:

  • input – The input unit.

  • unit_multiplier – Pointer to a double float variable for the unit_multiplier. This unit_multiplier will be scaled to make the new quantity’s numerical value consistent with the new unit. Thus, the initial value for the unit_multiplier should be non-zero.

Returns:

The new unit.

SIUnitRef SIUnitByTakingNthRoot(SIUnitRef input, uint8_t root, double *unit_multiplier, OCStringRef *error)

Returns the unit by dividing the numerator and denominator exponents by an integer.

The numerator and denominator exponents in a valid unit can only take on integer values. If this function cannot return a valid unit then it will return NULL.

Parameters:

  • input – The unit.

  • root – The integer root.

  • unit_multiplier – Pointer to a double float variable for the unit_multiplier. This unit_multiplier will be scaled to make the new quantity’s numerical value consistent with the new unit. Thus, the initial value for the unit_multiplier should be non-zero.

  • error – An OCString describing the error.

Returns:

The nth root unit.

SIUnitRef SIUnitByReducing(SIUnitRef theUnit, double *unit_multiplier)

Returns the unit by reducing the numerator and denominator exponents to their lowest integer values.

Parameters:

  • theUnit – The unit.

  • unit_multiplier – Pointer to a double float variable for the unit_multiplier. This unit_multiplier will be scaled to make the new quantity’s numerical value consistent with the new unit. Thus, the initial value for the unit_multiplier should be non-zero.

Returns:

The reduced unit.

SIUnitRef SIUnitByMultiplying(SIUnitRef theUnit1, SIUnitRef theUnit2, double *unit_multiplier, OCStringRef *error)

Returns the unit obtained by multiplying two units and reducing the dimensionality numerator and denominator exponents to their lowest integer values.

Parameters:

  • theUnit1 – The first unit.

  • theUnit2 – The second unit.

  • unit_multiplier – Pointer to a double float variable for the unit_multiplier. This unit_multiplier will be scaled to make the new quantity’s numerical value consistent with the new unit. Thus, the initial value for the unit_multiplier should be non-zero.

  • error – An OCString describing the error.

Returns:

The new unit.

SIUnitRef SIUnitByMultiplyingWithoutReducing(SIUnitRef theUnit1, SIUnitRef theUnit2, double *unit_multiplier, OCStringRef *error)

Returns the unit obtained by multiplying two units.

Parameters:

  • theUnit1 – The first unit.

  • theUnit2 – The second unit.

  • unit_multiplier – Pointer to a double float variable for the unit_multiplier. This unit_multiplier will be scaled to make the new quantity’s numerical value consistent with the new unit. Thus, the initial value for the unit_multiplier should be non-zero.

  • error – An OCString describing the error.

Returns:

The new unit.

  • theUnit2 – The second unit.

Returns:

The new unit.

Returns:

SIUnitRef SIUnitByRaisingToAPower(SIUnitRef input, double power, double *unit_multiplier, OCStringRef *error)

Returns the unit obtained by raising a unit to a power and reducing the dimensionality numerator and denominator exponents to their lowest integer values.

Parameters:

  • input – The unit.

  • power – The power to raise the unit to.

  • unit_multiplier – Pointer to a double float variable for the unit_multiplier. This unit_multiplier will be scaled to make the new quantity’s numerical value consistent with the new unit. Thus, the initial value for the unit_multiplier should be non-zero.

  • error – An OCString describing the error.

Returns:

The new unit.

Returns the unit obtained by raising a unit to a power.

  • power – The power to raise the unit to.

  • unit_multiplier – Pointer to a double float variable for the unit_multiplier. This unit_multiplier will be scaled to make the new quantity’s numerical value consistent with the new unit. Thus, the initial value for the unit_multiplier should be non-zero.

  • error – An OCString describing the error.

Returns:

The new unit.

SIUnitRef SIUnitForSymbol(OCStringRef symbol, double *unit_multiplier, OCStringRef *error)

Returns the unit with symbol, if valid.

Parameters:

  • symbol – The derived symbol.

  • unit_multiplier – Pointer to a double float variable for the unit_multiplier. This unit_multiplier will be scaled to make the new quantity’s numerical value consistent with the new unit. Thus, the initial value for the unit_multiplier should be non-zero.

  • error – An OCString describing the error.

Returns:

The unit or NULL if unit with derived symbol is not valid.

  • finalUnit – The final unit.

void SIUnitShow(SIUnitRef theUnit)

Shows a short descriptor of the unit.

Parameters:

  • theUnit – The unit.

void SIUnitShowFull(SIUnitRef theUnit)

Shows a long descriptor of the unit.

Parameters:

  • theUnit – The unit.

bool SIUnitsLibraryImperialVolumes(void)

Returns a boolean indicating if library uses imperial volumes for gallon, quart, pint, fluid ounce, tablespoon, and teaspoon.

If true, the US unit symbols are appended with ‘US’, i.e. galUS, qtUS, ptUS, etc… If false, the imperial symbols are appended with ‘UK’, i.e. galUK, qtUK, ptUK, etc…

Returns:

The boolean result.

void SIUnitsLibrarySetImperialVolumes(bool value)

Sets the library to use imperial volumes for gallon, quart, pint, fluid ounce, tablespoon, and teaspoon.

If true, the US unit symbols are appended with ‘US’, i.e. galUS, qtUS, ptUS, etc… If false, the imperial symbols are appended with ‘UK’, i.e. galUK, qtUK, ptUK, etc…

Parameters:

  • value – Boolean value indicating whether to use imperial volumes.

OCMutableDictionaryRef SIUnitGetLibrary(void)

Gets a copy of the library of units.

Returns:

A OCMutableDictionary containing the units.

void SIUnitSetLibrary(OCMutableDictionaryRef newUnitsLibrary)

Sets the library of units.

Parameters:

  • newUnitsLibrary – The new units library.

void SIUnitLibraryShow(void)

Shows a description of every unit in the library.

void SIUnitLibraryShowFull(void)

Shows a full description of every unit in the library.

Returns:

Returns:

An OCArray containing the root units.

OCArrayRef SIUnitCreateArrayOfRootUnitsForQuantity(OCStringRef quantity, OCStringRef *error)

Parameters:

  • quantity – The quantity.

  • error – An OCString describing the error.

Returns:
